Refuge services have been implemented to provide safe crisis accommodation, 41 emotional support and advocacy for this vulnerable group of individuals [2]. When 42 considering the design of refuges, an interdisciplinary and collaborative approach is needed, 43 with input from a range of stakeholders. Healthcare professionals can provide important 44 insights as family violence and homelessness are major causes of physical and mental harm. 45 The contribution from architecture and landscape is also essential because of the need for 46 good design principles to be used in creating both permanent and temporary 47 accommodation. However, most importantly, the concerns, preferences, and perspectives 48 of individuals who access and provide refuge services must be sought in order to create safe 49 spaces that are conducive to the needs of this diverse group. 50 This paper describes an authentic interdisciplinary learning experience where 51 nursing, landscape and architecture students engaged with refuge service providers and 52 women who were victims of domestic violence, to gain insights into their needs and 53 preferences in relation to the design of women's refuges. This real-world learning 54 experience provided an empathic 'lens' and enabled students to appreciate the lived 55 experience of service users. Additionally, by working collaboratively with other disciplines, 56 sharing knowledge, understandings and ideas, they were able to imagine possible 57 alternatives to existing refuge spaces. 58 This unique learning experience was informed by the philosophical tenets of 59 empathy. While previous studies have reported benefits of empathy in the 63 fields of nursing [5] and more recently in the fields of architecture and design studio 64 learning [6], limited studies have examined the impact of collaborative learning experiences 65 involving various disciplines working together to develop real-world understandings of the 66 lived experience of homelessness and domestic violence. The impact of this interdisciplinary 67 learning experience on nursing, landscape and architecture students' empathy levels were 68 measured using the Comprehensive State Empathy Scale (CSES). 69 70Literature Review 71 The word empathy comes from the German term, Einfühlung, meaning 'feeling into' 72 [7]. The theory of Einfühlung first appeared in philosophy in 1778 with Herder writing on 73 "body truth" and was further examined by Vischer in 1873 who stated that "the result of the 74 spatial relationship with an object is an increase or decrease in our vital sensation." Further 75 studies by Schmarsow and Wolfflin in 1886 explored the connection between breathing and 76 cardiac movements with spatial experience [8]. In the early 1900s, empathy was understood 77 as a projection of feelings onto the world. In the 1950s however, the experimental 78 psychologist Rosalind Cartwright proposed empathy as an interpersonal exchange, rejecting 79 projection in preference for "true" empathy - the accurate understanding of another's 80 feelings. More recently the discovery of mirror neurones by neuroscientists has linked 81 empathy with personal relationships [9].. It is made The copyright holder for this preprint (which was this version posted April 11, 2019. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/605097doi: bioRxiv preprint 582 In contemporary discourse, empathy is commonly understood as the ability to 83 accurately understand or feel what another person is experiencing, or to be able to place 84 oneself in their context. Empathy requires the perception and articulation of the emotional 85 state of another and results in a range of responses, often including a desire to help or an 86 ability to experience a similar emotional state. There are two principal issues that need to 87 be understood in the context of this research - the difference between "cognitive" and 88 "affective" empathy, and whether empathy is understood as a "trait" or "state" condition 89 [10]. 90 Cognitive empathy refers to the accurate perception of another person's perspective 91 or mental state (feeling into), whereas affective empathy involves an ability to experience 92 actual feelings or emotions that are consistent with another person, that is, "feeling with" 93 or "feeling concern for" the other [10]. Krznaric proposes that empathy is the combination 94 of the ability to perceive and share (affective) as well as to think and act (cognitive). This 95 kind of empathetic relationship describes a balance between looking inwards and looking 96 outwards; and stepping outside of ourselves to explore the perspectives of another person 97 people [11]. 98 Bloom argues, controversially, that affective empathy is often privileged over 99 cognitive empathy, leading to inaccurate decisions, based on incorrect perceptions of 100 another's emotional state or value judgements of another's experience. Bloom proposes 101 that cognitive empathy - the ability to perceive and act from an objective position, requires 102 understanding another, without needing to emotionally match the other [12]. This is a 103 perspective reiterated by Zurek [13]. Empathy is also viewed as both a 'trait' (predisposed . In healthcare, empathy is integral to therapeutic relationships, allowing 108 nurses to respond appropriately to the emotional needs of patients, to recognize their 109 psychological status and to respond with understanding and insight [15]. A body of research 110 attests to the benefits of empathic interactions between healthcare professionals and 111 patients. Such benefits include decreased levels of patient anxiety and depression [16], and 112 increased levels of emotional wellbeing, satisfaction and adherence to treatment regimens 113 [17}. A wide range of physiological outcomes have also been attributed to empathic 114 encounters including improved wound healing, level of immunity, and cancer survival rates 115 [18]; and lower blood pressure levels, pain diabetic complications [19]. Empathic 116 interactions also enhance healthcare professionals' job satisfaction, resilience and coping 117 skills [16-17]. 118 Integration of empathy in design programs has become increasingly common in 119 recent years, although it is not often promoted as a graduate attribute, being referenced 120 almost exclusively in relation to understanding user requirements rather than as a design 121 skill. Focus on user-focused design thinking has shown that empathy aids in developing an 122 understanding of the problem that can lead to more successful design outcomes including 123 objects, buildings and urban environments. A spatial understanding in terms of empathetic 124 response tends to involve "an attempt to trace both aesthetic effect and the meaning of 125 spatial form ... back to the human body and its sensations" [20].. Nowak describes the human tendency to anthropomorphize 128 and animate nature, facilitating an understanding of strange phenomena and ascribing life 129 and feelings to the inanimate elements of nature [7]. This suggests a more constructed idea 130 of empathetic understanding that relates to material and spatial function. 131 Lifchez [21], Ghajargar and Longo [22] both discuss the manifestation of empathy in 132 the design process and the resulting communication between designer and client. Hess and 133 Fila explore the notion that visualisation of empathetic thinking is demonstrated by 134 students' ability to integrate user requirements in the design brief development of a project 135 and then in design outcomes, describing these as "empathetic pathways" [6]. 136 In neither healthcare nor design studies, has the value of empathy within a 137 collaborative learning experience involving nursing, landscape and architecture students 138 working together to develop real-world understandings of the lived experience of 139 homelessness and domestic violence been explored. Thus, the project described in this 140 paper sought to address this gap in the literature. 141 142 Methodology 143 Aim 144 The aim of this study was to examine the impact of an interdisciplinary learning experience 145 on nursing, architecture and design students' empathy towards women seeking refuge 146 services. 147. The nursing 167 students were enrolled in a third-year elective subject focused on women's health and 168 including content on domestic and family violence and homelessness. Statistical research and current media coverage of domestic 178 violence and refuge provision were examined with a focus on spatial provisions and 179 programmatic requirements. 180 Landscape students were enrolled in a third-year design studio, which required the 181 development of a scheme for a real-life refuge. This subject required innovative responses 182 to community and stakeholder requirements for community landscape projects with an 183 exploration of the biological and therapeutic characteristics of plants. 184 The students from all disciplines met on three occasions to collaborate about the 185 design of the women's refuge. The first meeting involved students working in mixed 186 discipline teams to research the healthcare and social needs of women and children who 187 accessed refuges, identifying typical scenarios for women accessing refuge services, and 188 exploring their physical, mental, emotional and spatial needs. The knowledge acquired by 189 the nursing students during their placement experiences was shared with the design 190 students, so as to help them understand and frame user profiles in a more empathic and 191 realistic manner. This exercise aimed to provide foundational knowledge about the varied 192 needs of refuge users. . The CSES was previously developed to 217 evaluate the impact of an educational experience on participants' empathy towards specific 218 people or groups over a brief time period. It measures both cognitive and affective 219 empathy, as well as state empathy (at a point in time). [25] The scale includes 30 items and 220 takes 10-15 minutes to complete. Each CSES item is scored using a five-point Likert scale 221 with response ranges from 1 (completely untrue) to 5 (completely true), with higher scores 222 reflecting higher empathy levels. Previous psychometric testing of the CSES revealed good 223 internal consistency with a Cronbach's alpha (CA) of 0.96 for the overall scale. 224 225 Data Analysis 226 Statistical analyses were performed using the statistical program SPSS (version 22). Data 227 distribution was assessed by numerical methods included assessment of Z-score for 228 skewness and kurtosis, Shapiro-Wilk's test, and by visual methods including inspection of 229 histograms and Q-Q plots for pre-test and post-test total scores. The Z-score is the number 230 of standard deviations a value lies away from the mean and higher absolute Z-scores 231 correspond to lower p-values. A Z-score of ±1.96 equates to a p-value of 0.05 in a two-tailed 232 test. If data were normally distributed, parametric tests were performed, otherwise, non- 233 parametric tests were used. [30] However, empathy is one of the strongest negative 367 correlates of prejudice [31] providing a lens through which women experiencing 368 homelessness can be better understood and addressed. 369 The study described in this paper sought to examine impact of an authentic 370 interdisciplinary learning experience on nursing, architecture and landscape students' 371 empathy towards women and children who access refuge services as a result of 372 homelessness and/or domestic violence. Prior to the study we assumed that there would be 373 a pre-post increase in empathy levels in all students, but that the increase may be less for 374 nursing students who were frequently exposed to situations and scenarios designed to 375 increase empathy towards vulnerable groups. 376 The results indicated that nursing students' pre-test empathy levels were markedly 377 higher than those of architecture and landscape students, and that changes in pre-post 378 empathy scores for this cohort was minimal. This possibly reflects a dispositional tendency - 379 nursing fundamentally involves a commitment to understanding and responding to human 380 suffering - so that the nursing students commenced the study with higher levels of empathy 381 and were therefore less likely to experience a significant change over the 12-week study 382 period. 383 The increase in landscape students' empathy was approximately twice as much as 384 the nursing students, whereas architecture students' empathy levels decreased by a similar . These results were unanticipated outcomes of the study but may be explained, at 386 least in part, by the gender and age distribution of the participants. 387 There was significant variation in gender within the overall sample, with more male 388 than female landscape students, compared to architecture students who were 389 predominantly male and nursing students who were all female. The generally accepted fact 390 that males are less empathetic than women [32] may have influenced by the gendered 391 nature of the results. The range in ages, and the relationship between life experiences and 392 empathy levels may have also influenced the results as the landscape students were a 393 slightly older group, although this is only an assumption. Additionally, no clear relationship 394 could be found between empathy levels and ethnic diversity, with the sample that was 395 predominantly South East Asian and Caucasian, and a small number of Middle Eastern 396 students. 397 Other reasons for these results include the nursing students' greater exposure to 398 refuge users in their field of study, and consequently, their understanding of human 399 suffering may be more refined. Architecture and landscape students may have never dealt 400 with design in the context of social issues which include human cruelty and suffering. The 401 teaching and learning activities for the three cohorts of students, each enrolled in different 402 subjects, may also have contributed to the outcomes.
